newsitem.title: USA: Blue chips fall on profit-taking, weak tobacco shares.
newsitem.headline: Blue chips fall on profit-taking, weak tobacco shares.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks fell Wednesday as investors called time out after a three-session winning streak and tobacco shares plunged as a crucial cigarette liability trial neared an end.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 31.44 points at 5,689.82 after gaining 56 points from Friday to Tuesday.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 1,225 to 1,048 on moderate volume of 348 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
"We had basic profit-taking in stocks," said Peter Cardillo, director of research of Westfalia Investments.
Analysts said the stock of Philip Morris and other tobacco companies bowed under the weight of mounting industry lawsuits and signs of increased government oversight.

"Philip Morris is accounting for the cloud over the market," said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist at Fahnestock & Co. Philip Morris tumbled 3-7/8 to 87-5/8, and was off sharply from its 52-week high of 107-38.

Tobacco shares were already under pressure Wednesday by news that Michigan became the 13th state to sue the industry -- a day after Arizona and Kansas filed suit -- and as a key cigarette trial in Indianapolis was nearing an end.
In another development, the White House said President Clinton was expected to say on Friday that he accepts a Food and Drug Administration recommendation that tobacco be regulated as a drug.

"It seems to be one problem after another. It's a negative for Philip Morris and other tobacco stocks but I don't think it'll affect the rest of the market," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp.
Ackerman said, "There's no telling how investors will value tobacco stocks from here on in. It's certainly not an area where an investor can jump in."
Wall Street was still mindful of the stiff selling in tobacco shares in the wake of an Aug. 8 Florida jury ruling against the industry in a suit filed by a smoker.
Among tobacco shares, RJR Nabisco, parent of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, lost 1-1/8 to 25-3/8, smokeless tobacco maker UST Inc fell 7/8 to 30-7/8 and Loews lost 1-1/4 to 76-5/8.
Meanwhile, late buying in technology issues lifted the recently battered Nasdaq Composite index, which closed up 2.17 points to 1,126.84.
International Business Machines rose 1-7/8 to 112-3/8, Intel added 3/4 to 80-1/4 and Cisco Systems added 1-1/4 to 56-1/4.
Analysts said trading was still seasonally slow.

"We're operating in a vacuum. The only thing to stimulate stocks is bonds," said Larry Wachtel, a Prudential Securities market analyst. "There's not much volume, not many players and not much conviction."
In the bond market, the Treasury's key 30-year bond lost 15/32 and its yield rose to 6.84 percent from 6.80 percent at Tuesday's close.
Tobacco stocks nonetheless remained a focus, with traders awaiting the outcome of the Indiana court case. The jury is expected to get the case Thursday.
"If they win, tobacco stocks will be saved. If not, tobacco stocks will get another whacking," Wachtel said.
Among individual stocks, Newbridge Networks jumped 11 to 59-3/8 after the maker of networking equipment laid to rest lingering investor fears with a solid first-quarter report.
Jenny Craig slumped 5-7/8 to 11-3/8. The company late Tuesday blamed new weight-loss drugs for recent soft demand for its weight-loss programmes.
Rexene Corp. fell 2-1/4 to 10-1/2 after privately-held Huntsman Corp. said late Tuesday that it was withdrawing its $460 million bid for the chemical firm.
Oracle lost 1-1/8 to 37-7/8. Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock after its recent run-up.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 0.62 to 665.07. The American Stock Exchange index was off 1.61 to 557.68.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.50 to 356.11. The average share was off 5 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 6,496.605 down 7.963 or 0.12 percent.
